Award.AwardTitle: Time Domain Numerical Methods for Electromagnetic Wave Propagation Problems in Complex Dispersive Dielectrics
Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to develop and analyze efficient numerical methods for forward problems in the time domain involving the propagation and scattering of electromagnetic waves in complex dielectric media that display physical dispersion due to multiple polarization mechanisms. The forward solution of dispersive, time-dependent electromagnetic wave systems is often used to obtain safety standards regarding exposure of humans to high-energy electromagnetic fields. These numerical simulations can also be utilized in an inverse-problem formulation, for example, in cancer detection. In imaging for medical applications, one seeks to investigate the internal structure of an object (the human body) by means of electromagnetic fields at sub-infrared frequencies to detect and characterize cancer or other anomalies by studying changes in the dielectric properties (such as permittivity, conductivity, relaxation times, etc.) of tissues. Electromagnetic wave propagation in complex dispersive media is governed by the time-dependent Maxwell's equations coupled to equations that describe the evolution of the induced macroscopic polarization. The behavior of the media's macroscopic polarization may include first-order relaxation mechanisms of Debye type, used in modeling polar materials such as water and living tissue, as well as second-order mechanisms of Lorentz type. These two mechanisms will be used as model problems. The investigator and a graduate student will develop operator-splitting techniques along with mixed finite element methods for electromagnetic wave propagation in dispersive dielectrics. Additionally, fictitious domain methods will be applied to wave-scattering problems in these materials. Efficient absorbing layers for terminating computational boundaries involving dispersive dielectrics will be constructed and analyzed. Analysis of well-posedness, stability, and convergence of the new methods will be conducted. The graduate student will study existing simulation methods and make comparisons with the newly developed computational techniques.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we have considered novel and efficient numerical methods and their analyses for the simulation of electromagnetic waves in linear dispersive media. By a dispersive material we mean a dielectric (insulator) in which planar electromagnetic waves travel with phase velocities that depend on the frequency of the propagating waves. Dispersive materials embody physical dispersion, and incident waves in these media can spread and change shape, even when the medium is homogeneous. The physical dispersion of the medium and the response of the medium to the electromagnetic pulse is incorporated into a macroscopic quantity called the electric polarization. Wave propagation in such media is modeled by Maxwell's equations along with auxiliary equations that model the evolution of the electric polarization.

Ultra-short pulsed electromagnetic fields are used in a wide variety of applications in radar, environmental and medical imaging to evaluate the internal structure of dispersive objects for detecting and characterizing anomalies. This is done by studying changes in the dielectric properties (such as permittivity, conductivity, and relaxation times) of the materials under consideration. Examples are the noninvasive evaluation of tissues and organs in cancer detection, nondestructive investigation of materials for cracks, remote sensing of buried or hidden terrestrial objects from orbiting satellites, and climate assessment in atmosphere.

Numerical simulations in the time domain of wave propagation in dispersive materials can help in understanding the short-pulse response of these media, and can be used to obtain threshold levels of safe exposure of humans to high energy electromagnetic fields. These simulations can also be used in inverse problem formulations in many  applications.  Thus, the focus of this project, which is the development of efficient discrete forward solvers for dispersive Maxwell's equations which are accurate and stable, is important in order to construct reliable prediction and imaging tools.

Along with students and collaborators, the PI has constructed and analyzed a variety of time domain numerical methods including high order finite difference and finite element methods, dispersion optimized edge element methods and unconditionally stable operator splitting methods for electromagnetic wave propagation problems. In addition topics such as the stability of perfectly matched layer models, numerical techniques for obtaining accurate solutions to problems involving interfaces of discontinuity in the material parameters, and convergence analyses of numerical techniques for the dispersive Maxwell's equations have also been considered.

All numerical methods for pulsed wave propagation have spurious dispersion error that can become significant as waves travel over large distances in the numerical grid. The analysis of dispersion error in these methods is important for providing users of these methods with guidelines on the optimum discretization parameters to use in order to reduce dispersion error. We have analyzed the dispersion error in several high order finite difference and finite element methods for the dispersive Maxwell's equations.

The research conducted in this project has resulted in several research publications, two masters theses, an REU project, and a PhD thesis that is in progress at Oregon State University. The PI has involved her graduate and undergraduate students in preparing manuscripts for publication.  In addition a new course on Computational Electromagnetics was created and taught at Oregon State University. The research conducted in this project has also been disseminated at local seminars and national conferences by the PI,
collaborators and graduate and undergraduate students.
